sub_topic: Finding eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a matrix using power iteration method
message_1:
Consider the matrix A:

A = [3 2 1; 2 4 2; 1 2 3]

Use the power iteration method to find the largest eigenvalue and corresponding eigenvector of A. Start with an initial guess of [1; 1; 1] and iterate until the difference between two consecutive guesses is less than or equal to 0.0001. Round your final answers to three decimal places.
message_2:
We will use the power iteration method to find the largest eigenvalue and corresponding eigenvector of A. We start with an initial guess of [1; 1; 1] and iterate until the difference between two consecutive guesses is less than or equal to 0.0001.

Matrix A:
[3 2 1]
[2 4 2]
[1 2 3]

Initial guess (x0):
[1]
[1]
[1]

Let's start the iteration process:

1st iteration:
x1 = A * x0 = [6; 8; 6]
Normalize x1: x1 = x1 / ||x1|| = [6/10; 8/10; 6/10] = [0.6; 0.8; 0.6]

2nd iteration:
x2 = A * x1 = [3.6; 6.4; 3.6]
Normalize x2: x2 = x2 / ||x2|| = [3.6/8; 6.4/8; 3.6/8] = [0.45; 0.8; 0.45]

3rd iteration:
x3 = A * x2 = [3.3; 6.1; 3.3]
Normalize x3: x3 = x3 / ||x3|| = [3.3/7.7; 6.1/7.7; 3.3/7.7] ≈ [0.429; 0.792; 0.429]

4th iteration:
x4 = A * x3 ≈ [3.221; 6.034; 3.221]
Normalize x4: x4 = x4 / ||x4|| ≈ [3.221/7.476; 6.034/7.476; 3.221/7.476] ≈ [0.431; 0.807; 0.431]

The difference between x4 and x3 is less than 0.0001, so we can stop the iteration process.

Now, we can find the largest eigenvalue using the Rayleigh quotient:
λ = (x4' * A * x4) / (x4' * x4) ≈ [0.431 0.807 0.431] * A * [0.431; 0.807; 0.431] / [0.431 0.807 0.431] * [0.431; 0.807; 0.431]

λ ≈ 7.999

So, the largest eigenvalue is approximately 8.000, and the corresponding eigenvector is approximately [0.431; 0.807; 0.431].
